'''Frank Carter Duckworth''' [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]] (born 26 December 1939 in [[Lytham St Annes]], [[Lancashire]])<ref name="ESPNcricinfo — Frank Duckworth — England">{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/england/content/player/462809.html|title=Frank Duckworth — England|work=[[ESPNcricinfo]]|publisher=[[ESPN]]|accessdate=31 December 2011}}</ref> is a retired [[English people|English]] [[statistician]], and is one of the two statisticians who developed the [[Duckworth–Lewis method]] of resetting targets in interrupted [[one-day cricket|one-day]] [[cricket]] matches.<ref>{{citation|title=First Night: Duckworth–Lewis: The odd couple getting even with the weather|journal=[[The Independent]]|date=16 May 1999| url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/first-night-duckworthlewis-the-odd-couple-getting-even-with--the-weather-1093982.html | location=London | first=Andrew | last=Longmore | accessdate=2 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=How two statisticians became stars|journal=[[New York Times]]|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2003/02/18/sports/18iht-cricket_ed3__6.html|date=18 February 2003 |  first=Huw | last=Richards | accessdate=2 May 2010}}</ref> He studied physics (BSc Hons 1961) and earned a PhD (1965) in metallurgy at the [[University of Liverpool]].<ref>{{citation|title=University of Liverpool Alumni Newsletter:Queen's Birthday Honours list 2010 |date=July 2010 |url=http://alumni.liv.ac.uk/NetCommunity/SSLPage.aspx?pid=969&frcrld=1&utm_source=alumnienewsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=enewsletterjuly2010}}</ref> Prior to his retirement, he worked as a mathematical scientist for the English [[nuclear power]] industry.<ref>[http://billboard.anu.edu.au/event_view.asp?id=37384&printerfriendly=true The D/L Method in One-day Cricket: Twelve years on]. Announcement for talk by Duckworth at the [[Australian National University]], 20 February  2009</ref> He is a consultant statistician to the [[International Cricket Council]],<ref>{{citation|title= Duckworth to review D/L method, slams Indian rival|url=http://sports.in.msn.com/t20wc2009/article.aspx?cp-documentid=3042371|publisher=[[MSN]]|date=17 June 2009|format= }} {{dead link|date=May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=Duckworth, Lewis to attend World Cup Forum in Antigua|journal=Jamaica Observer|date=3 December 2005|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/sports/html/20051202T220000-0500_93799_OBS_DUCKWORTH__LEWIS_TO_ATTEND_WORLD_CUP_FORUM_IN_ANTIGUA.asp|format=}} {{dead link|date=May 2010}}.</ref> and the editor of the [[Royal Statistical Society]]'s monthly news magazine, RSS News.<ref>[http://www.rss.org.uk/main.asp?page=1710 RSS News Editorial Team], Royal Statistical Society.</ref> He also served on the editorial board of ''[[Significance (magazine)|Significance]]'' before stepping down in 2010. In 2004 he delivered the Royal Statistical Society Schools Lecture, entitled ''Lies and Statistics''.<ref>[http://www.rss.org.uk/main.asp?page=1918 RSS Schools Lecture (Guy Lecture)] and [http://www.rss.org.uk/main.asp?page=2179 Past RSS Schools Lectures], Royal Statistical Society</ref>

Duckworth is also known for developing a system of quantifying personal [[risk perception]],<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/1999/jul/16/johnezard|journal=[[The Guardian]]|title=Riskometer measures life's ups and downs|date=16 July 1999 | location=London | first=John | last=Ezard | accessdate=2 May 2010}}</ref> now known as the "Duckworth scale".<ref>{{citation|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espnmag/story?id=3576125|title=Editor's blog|journal=[[ESPN Magazine]]|first=Gary|last=Belsky|date=8 September 2008}}</ref>

Duckworth was appointed [[Member of the Order of the British Empire]] (MBE) in the 2010 Birthday Honours.<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=59446 |date=12 June 2010 |startpage=15 |supp=yes }}</ref>
